events.originalText: Pakistani activist Malala Yousafzai (pictured) was severely injured by a Taliban gunman in a failed assassination attempt.* 2019 – Syrian civil war: Turkish forces began an offensive into north-eastern Syria following the withdrawal of U.S. troops from the region.
events.subtitle: Malala Yousafzai
events.headline: Malala Yousafzai Injured in Failed Assassination Attempt by Taliban

events.originalText: The Phantom of the Opera, a musical by Andrew Lloyd Webber and currently the longest-running Broadway show in history, opened in London's West End.
events.subtitle: The Phantom of the Opera (1986 musical)
events.headline: Turkish Forces Begin Offensive in North-Eastern Syria Following U.S. Troop Withdrawal

events.originalText: Nick Holonyak, an engineer for General Electric, gave the first public demonstration of a light-emitting diode.
events.subtitle: Nick Holonyak
events.headline: The Phantom of the Opera Opens in London's West End

events.originalText: A footman shot and killed two colleagues and wounded the lady of the house at Knowsley Hall, England.
events.subtitle: Knowsley Hall shootings
events.headline: Engineer Nick Holonyak Demonstrates First Light-Emitting Diode

events.originalText: World War II: American forces defeated the Japanese at the Third Battle of the Matanikau in Guadalcanal, Solomon Islands, reversing the Japanese victory a couple of weeks earlier.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Footman Shoots and Kills Colleagues at Knowsley Hall, England

events.originalText: World War I: The civilian authorities of Antwerp surrendered, allowing the German army to capture the city.
events.subtitle: World War I
events.headline: American Forces Defeat Japanese at Third Battle of the Matanikau in Guadalcanal

events.originalText: Carrying a cargo hold full of highly flammable chemicals, the ocean liner SS Volturno caught fire in the north Atlantic and sank, resulting in 136 deaths.
events.subtitle: SS Volturno (1906)
events.headline: Antwerp Surrenders to German Army in World War I

events.originalText: The Washington Monument  in Washington, D.C., at the time the world's tallest building, officially opened to the general public.
events.subtitle: Washington Monument
events.headline: SS Volturno Catches Fire and Sinks in North Atlantic, Resulting in 136 Deaths

events.originalText: War of the Sixth Coalition: Empress Marie-Louise of France issued decrees conscripting tens of thousands of teenagers, who became known as Marie-Louises.
events.subtitle: War of the Sixth Coalition
events.headline: Washington Monument Officially Opens in Washington, D.C.

events.originalText: The deadliest Atlantic hurricane on record began to impact the Caribbean, killing at least 20,000 people across the Antilles over the subsequent days.* 1793 – French Revolution: After a month-long siege, the leaders of Lyon surrendered, ending their revolt against the National Convention.
events.subtitle: Great Hurricane of 1780
events.headline: Empress Marie-Louise of France Conscribes Teenagers in War of the Sixth Coalition

events.originalText: European soldiers and Javanese collaborators massacred Chinese Indonesians in the port city of Batavia, modern-day Jakarta.
events.subtitle: 1740 Batavia massacre
events.headline: Deadliest Atlantic Hurricane on Record Hits Caribbean, Killing 20,000

events.originalText: Great Northern War: Russia defeated Sweden at the Battle of Lesnaya on the Russian–Polish border, in present-day Belarus.
events.subtitle: Great Northern War
events.headline: Leaders of Lyon Surrender After Month-Long Siege in French Revolution

events.originalText: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek wrote a letter to the Royal Society describing "animalcules" – the first known description of protozoa (pictured).
events.subtitle: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek
events.headline: European Soldiers Massacre Chinese Indonesians in Batavia
